pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 44030 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
September 2010 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Rural Health Insurance: 
Improving Provider Payment Methods 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 6 September 2010) 
 
Currency Unit –  yuan (CNY) 
CNY1.00 =  $0.1469 
$1.00 =  CNY6.8038 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CCMS  –  Center for the Cooperative Medical Scheme 
  DRHM  –  Department of Rural Health Management 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  MOH  –  Ministry of Health  
  NRCMS  –  New Rural Cooperative Medical Scheme 
  PRC  –  People's Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting Classification  –  Targeted intervention (TI-M) 
Sector (subsector)  –  Health and social protection (social protection) 
Theme (subthemes)  –  Social development (human development, other vulnerable groups) 
Location impact  –  Rural (low) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  A. Leung, Urban and Social Sectors Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  C. Bodart, Senior Health Specialist, EARD 
Team members  J. Jeugmans, Practice Leader (Health), Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department 
C. Peyron Bista, Social Sector Specialist, PRC Resident Mission, EARD 
W. Walker, Senior Social Development Specialist, EARD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In December 2009, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) 
to improve provider payment methods for rural health insurance. ADB undertook TA fact-finding 
in  March  2010  and  reached  agreement  with  the  government  regarding  the  TA's  impact, 
outcome, outputs, terms of reference for consulting services, cost estimates, financing plan, and 
implementation arrangements.1 The TA is in line with Strategy 20202 and the Operational Plan 
for Health3 under Strategy 2020.The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  In 2003, the PRC launched the New Rural Cooperative Medical Scheme (NRCMS), a 
health insurance scheme run by counties, to address the high out-of-pocket expenditures for 
health care in rural areas. Funding for NRCMS is provided by central and local governments on 
a per capita basis (CNY20 in 2003, CNY80 in 2009) and rural residents contribute a fixed 
amount on a voluntary basis (CNY10 in 2003, CNY20 in 2009). NRCMS has made great 
progress; in 2008, it covered 100% of counties, and in 2009, it enrolled 833 million people, 
resulting in an enrollment rate of 94%. NRCMS represents a major step toward a rural health 
financing system that is more equitable, through reducing out-of-pocket expenditures for health 
care, and also more efficient.  
 
3.  The level of financial protection provided by NRCMS has risen along with increases in 
the funding available for NRCMS, with the true reimbursement rate4 increasing from 25% in 
2004 to 41% in 2009. However, rising medical costs are reducing the financial protection of the 
insured,  especially  when  patients  suffer  from  catastrophic  illnesses.  Furthermore,  NRCMS 
reimburses primarily in-patient care, thereby creating an incentive to shift from low-cost out-
patient to costly in-patient care.  
 
4.  In the PRC, providers are paid primarily on a fee-for-service basis, which encourages 
excessive and expensive treatments. Providers have a tendency to increase their income by 
selling drugs and providing high-tech care. The additional funding available to health providers 
exerts an upward pressure on the cost of care without necessarily improving the quality of 
services. The 2009 Health System Reform in the PRC requires NRCMS to become more 
efficient in reducing the economic burden of illnesses for rural residents. A recent decision of the 
government requires at least 10% of counties to reform their provider payment methods under 
NRCMS by the end of 2010. 
 
5.  Although some counties have piloted different payment methods, there is no systematic 
approach in reforming payment mechanisms to providers. The TA will provide international 
experience  on  provider  payment  methods,  summarize  the  overall  experience  of  provider 
payment methods used by NRCMS, observe the implementation of a number of typical payment 
methods, document the successful experiences of counties that have carried out payment 
method reforms, and pilot selected payment methods. The TA will explore provider payment 
methods suitable for rural areas, which could be widely used by NRCMS after validation to 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 March 2010. 
2  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
3  ADB. 2008. An Operational Plan for Improving Health Access and Outcomes under Strategy 2020. Manila. 
4  The  true  reimbursement  rate  deducts  deductibles,  ceilings,  and  related  expenses  before  computing  the 
reimbursement rate.

2   
better control the cost of care, ensure the quality of health services, and minimize transaction 
costs. This would entail improving the way in which NRCMS purchases health services from 
hospitals on behalf of their members, including capacity building to improve contracting and 
negotiating skills, and improving monitoring of the quality of the services provided. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA aims to identify appropriate health provider payment methods to strengthen the 
health services purchasing capacity of NRCMS. The outcome of the TA will be for MOH to 
adopt policy recommendations on reforming provider payment methods for NRCMS. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 2. 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  Key outputs. The TA will deliver three outputs: (i) a study report on international and 
national experience, (ii) capacity-building material on payment methods, and (iii) dissemination 
of findings and recommendations. 
 
8.  Output  1:  Study  report  on  international  and  national  experience.  To  prepare 
recommendations for NRCMS on provider payment reform, the TA will (i) identify international 
experience and best practices in provider payment methods, especially for rural and remote 
areas; (ii) analyze the provider payment methods currently used under NRCMS; (iii) carry out 
selected field investigations in several counties considered of particular interest for the future 
reform of provider payment methods; (iv) draw lessons from pilot tests to be conducted in two 
counties; and (v) prepare a study report on NRCMS provider payment reform and international 
experience based on the results of items (i) – (iv).  
 
9.  Output 2: Capacity-building material on payment methods for health providers, 
NRCMS managers, and health authorities. The TA will (i) prepare and pilot test training 
materials based on the findings and recommendations of output 1; (ii) train selected health 
providers, NRCMS managers, and health authorities; and (iii) organize an overseas trip on 
provider payment methods for key decision-makers and implementers. 
 
10.  Output 3: Dissemination of findings and recommendations. Dissemination of results, 
which is essential to the success of the TA, will be carried out through (i) three multisectoral 
workshops for policy makers and key implementers; (ii) preparation of policy recommendations 
for MOH on reforming provider payment  methods; (iii) a final dissemination conference to 
present the TA's findings and recommendations to MOH and other relevant decision-makers 
and stakeholders at the national and local levels; and (iv) preparation of a knowledge product on 
provider payment methods for NRCMS, targeting decision-makers and technical staff.  
 
11.  The  TA  consultants  will  report  regularly  to  the  project  steering  committee  on  the 
progress  of  activities  under  outputs  1–3  and  fine-tune  final  recommendations  to  MOH  for 
reforming provider payment methods.

3
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $380,000 equivalent.  The government has 
requested ADB to finance $300,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-Other  Sources).  The  TA  will  finance 
consulting services, including (i) external resource persons for draft reviews and other focused 
inputs;  (ii)  a  conference,  workshops,  and  training;  (iii)  domestic  and  overseas  travel;  and  
(iv) field work and survey costs. The government will finance the balance of the cost, equivalent 
to $80,000, through provision of office space and equipment (computers), communications 
facilities for consultants, remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff, and other in-kind 
contributions.  Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 22 months from October 2010 to July 2012, with policy 
recommendations adopted by MOH shortly after July 2012.  
 
14.  The Department of Rural Health Management (DRHM), MOH will be the executing 
agency for the TA, and the Center for the Cooperative Medical Scheme (CCMS), MOH will be 
the implementing agency. DRHM and CCMS will each designate a senior staff member as the 
TA  focal  point,  and  will  facilitate  the  consultants’  access  to  participating  central  and  local 
government agencies, as well as to materials, data, and documents required by the TA. CCMS 
will provide a furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access for the consultants 
and arrange the logistics for the field trips. 
 
15.  Under the supervision of DRHM, CCMS will be responsible for day-to-day oversight and 
support  of  the  consultants’  work.  The  study  report  (output  1)  and  TA  findings  and 
recommendations (output 3) will be distributed to key stakeholders for comments to maximize 
the impact of the TA. 
 
16.  A  project  steering  committee  will  be  set  up,  chaired  by  DRHM  and  composed  of 
representatives from the Department of Social Security, Ministry of Finance (MOF); Department 
of Social Assistance, Ministry of Civil Affairs; Department of Pricing, National Development and 
Reform Commission; and Department of Planning and Finance, MOH. The purpose of the 
steering  committee  is  to  build  broad  support  across  key  agencies  and  disseminate  major 
outputs to relevant ministries and agencies. Coordination will take place with the World Health 
Organization and the World Bank (who are involved in health financing activities in the PRC) 
through informal meetings and participation in the three workshops to discuss provider payment 
mechanisms. 
 
17.  In dialogue with DRHM, ADB will engage national consultants for a total of 12 person-
months. ADB will recruit the consultants on an individual basis to ensure their timely fielding and 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to time). The consultants will be chosen based on their academic qualifications and relevant 
work experience. The consultants will include a team leader and senior health economist (6 
person-months), a senior policy and evaluation  specialist (4 person-months), and a senior 
health financing specialist with strong expertise in survey methodology (2 person-months). The 
consultants  will  have  strong  expertise  in  health  financing  and  health  insurance  with 
specialization in provider payment methods, and practical experience with NRCMS. The team 
leader, with the assistance of the other two consultants, will be responsible for producing the

4   
TA's outputs and deliverables effectively and on time and for organizing and carrying out all TA 
activities. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The  consultants,  through  the  CCMS,  will  submit  to  the  government  and  ADB  the 
following four reports, which will be prepared in Chinese and English:  
 
(i)  an inception report within 1 month of commencement of services for discussion 
during ADB's inception mission, with an implementation plan, the description of 
the  division  of  labor  among  consultants  for  the  execution  of  the  TA,  a 
coordination  mechanism  with  CCMS,  and  an  outline  of  the  study  report  on 
NRCMS provider payment reform and international experience (output 1);  
 
(ii)  an interim report on the progress made on activities under outputs 1 and 2;  
 
(iii)  a draft final report, which will include the study report (output 1), the training 
material (output 2), and the knowledge product (output 3); and 
 
(iv)  a final report, which will include the finalized items included in the draft final 
report and the policy recommendations on reforming provider payment methods 
for NRCMS.  
 
19.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To  facilitate 
implementation, ADB may establish an advance payment facility for MOH to support certain 
agreed cash expenditures, including workshops, a conference, and the implementation of field 
work and survey activities, with details of the proposed activities, including cost estimates, being 
submitted via DRHM to ADB for approval. ADB may also make certain direct payments (e.g., for 
workshop venues).  
 
20.  MOF has proposed to delegate to DRHM the TA administration under the Enhanced 
Partnership on TA Delegation.5 A capacity assessment conducted by ADB's Central Operations 
Services Office has concluded that DRHM has the capacity to administer the TA given that (i) 
the assignment is small, (ii) only individual consultants will be recruited, and (iii) a staff member 
from CCMS has attended a training course on TA delegation that was held in Beijing from 17 to 
21 May 2010.   
 
21.  Through informal meetings involving ADB staff and MOH officials, the TA will be linked to 
the health component of the TA for Supporting Fiscal Reforms in High Priority Sectors, which 
will explore public financing mechanisms to fund township hospitals, community health services, 
and village clinics.6  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Rural  Health  Insurance:  Improving 
Provider Payment Methods, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
5  MOU signed between MOF and ADB in November 2009. 
6  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Supporting Fiscal Reforms in High Priority 
Sectors. Manila (TA 7095-PRC, approved on 10 July).

8  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
1.  A total of 12 person-months of consulting services will be required. All outputs (including 
attachments) will be presented in English and Chinese. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Senior Health Economist (national, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The  team  leader,  a  PhD,  will  have  strong  expertise  in  health  financing  and  health 
insurance, and practical experience with the New Rural Cooperative Medical Scheme (NRCMS). 
He or she will demonstrate knowledge and skills in capacity needs assessment, development of 
training materials, and conduct of training and awareness programs. The expert will: 
 
(i)  Serve as the team leader of the consultants and ensure timely completion of all 
outputs of the policy and advisory technical assistance (TA).  
 
(ii)  Critically review ongoing provider payment reforms in NRCMS and throughout 
the world, especially in remote and rural areas. 
 
(iii)  Design  the  overall  and  selected  field  investigations,  including  evaluation,  of 
provider payment reforms in the People’s Republic of China. 
 
(iv)  Organize participatory consultations with key stakeholders (beneficiaries, local 
government authorities, NRCMS service providers, and health professionals). 
Such consultations will also serve to understand the NCRMS from a gender 
perspective, in terms of access, participation, use, and provider service delivery 
and payment. 
 
(v)  Implement  training  activities,  including  (a)  preparation  of  capacity-building 
material  on  payment  methods  for  health  providers,  NRCMS  managers,  and 
health  authorities  in  line  with  the  study  report  on  international  and  national 
experience; (b) pilot testing and finalization of the training materials; and (c) 
training of selected health providers, NRCMS managers, and health authorities. 
 
(vi)  Assist in carrying out selected field investigations in several counties considered 
of particular interest for future reform of provider payment methods.  
 
(vii)  Assist in implementing pilot tests in two counties.  
 
(viii)  Prepare a knowledge product on provider payment methods for NRCMS. 
 
(ix)  Prepare policy recommendations for the Ministry of Health on reforming provider 
payment methods, including ways of improving the equity of contributions to 
NRCMS. 
 
(x)  Organize a final conference on findings and recommendations. 
 
(xi)  Prepare the final TA report.

Appendix 3   9
 
B.  Senior Policy and Evaluation Specialist (national, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  The national senior policy and evaluation specialist, a health economist, with at least a 
master’s level qualification, will have expertise in health financing and health insurance, as well 
as practical experience in conducting field investigations and pilot tests, and in evaluating the 
results. The expert will: 
 
(i)  Prepare  a  study  report  on  experience  and  successful  practice  in  payment 
methods in NRCMS. 
 
(ii)  Design, carry out, and evaluate the field investigations and pilot tests. 
 
(iii)  Assist with survey activities as requested. 
 
(iv)  Assist with training activities as requested. 
 
(v)  Assist the team leader in the timely completion of the TA outputs as required. 
 
C.  Senior Health Financing Specialist (national, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The national senior health financing specialist, with at least a master’s level qualification, 
will have strong expertise in health financing and health insurance, and practical experience 
with NRCMS. The expert will: 
 
(i)  Provide guidance in the overall design of the TA. 
 
(ii)  Provide guidance in the design of the survey, field investigations, pilot tests, and 
training activities. 
 
(iii)  Take part in the survey, field investigations, and pilot tests. 
 
(iv)   Assist the team leader in the timely completion of the TA's outputs as required. 
 
(v)  Provide recommendations to the government for strengthening rural health.
